timeline.message:
Allow EndSaga on other MessageHandlingMembers

Adjust the isEndingHandler validation to simply validate the existence
of the EndSaga annotation. Doing so opens up this annotation to be
placed on DeadlineHandler annotated methods too. Tests/assertions should
 be included to validate a Saga to be ended on a deadline handler yes/no

#1469

Add DeadlineManager centric validation

Add assertions to the deadline manager test suite which validate the
"life" of a Saga when using deadlines

#1469

timeline.bodyText:
for backwards compatibility, wouldn't it be better to check for the SagaMethodMessageHandlingMember::isEndingHandler and in the orElse do the handler.hasAnnotation(EndSaga.class).
I also think that the isEndingHandler is invoked for each Saga Handler invocation. I'm wondering if it wouldn't be better to wrap an Event Handler annotated with @EndSaga with the behavior to end the Saga using SagaLifecycle.end()
timeline.author: abuijze

replies.bodyText: Just looked at the code. It's better to deprecate the isEndlingHandler method and create a MessageHandlerWrapper that reacts on the EndSaga annotation. That way, there is no need to inspect annotations for each call, but rather only during initialization.
replies.author: abuijze

replies.bodyText:
Was already in doubt whether I could "get away" with this simple, albeit hacky, solution.
Just added a dedicated handler enhancer definition and handling member to achieve the same.
Let me know what you think.
replies.author: smcvb

timeline.message:
Add HandlerEnhancerDefinition for EndSaga

Introduce a HandlerEnhancerDefinition which wraps handlers annotated
with EndSaga. When wrapping, the handle method should invoke
SagaLifecycle.end() prior to returning the result. This allows for the
deprecation of the SagaMethodMessageHandlingMember#isEndingHandler
method, as well as the removal of validating if it's an ending handler
inside the AnnotatedAggregate

#1469

timeline.bodyText:
If you are concerned about backwards compatibility on this one, then simply ignoring the value here isn't an option. It will change the behavior to a degree that you'd much rather have a compilation error.
Since this is not likely to be a component others use directly, I suggest removing the constructor instead.
